issues.title: port dotnet/corefx#24055 to our copy of the ManagedWebSocket class
issues.body:
We don't have any place to test this code unfortunately. This is a short term fix for Preview 1. Once we are able to consume an OOB API and get rid of this copy, the code will go away.

cc @stephentoub

issues.title: THIS ISSUE TRACKER IS CLOSED - use the Home repo issue tracker
issues.body:
Hello, this issue tracker is no longer used. Please log new issues here: https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues

For information about this change, see https://github.com/aspnet/Announcements/issues/283

commit.message: Use MSBuild to set NuGet feeds instead of NuGet.config
Use MicrosoftNETCoreApp21PackageVersion to determine the runtime framework in netcoreapp2.1
Update samples and tests to target netcoreapp2.1

Pin tool and package versions to make builds more repeatable

Part of aspnet/Universe#575
Increase Minimum Version of Visual Studio to 15.3.0
Use PackageLineup to manage PackageReference versions
Ensure fallback to curl after failed wget

Fix syntax warning when running build.sh on older versions of bash

[ci skip]

Update bootstrappers to use the compiled version of KoreBuild

[ci skip]

issue_comments.body: :shipit:
:shipit:
:shipit:
The overwrite should be optional. Different implementations will have different features, bugs, perf, etc..
Sure maybe a flag to overwrite then.
:shipit:
7.5.1 - Send a close frame with invalid UTF8 payload - Clean close with protocol error or invalid utf8 code or dropped TCP.

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-5.6

```
   Text

      The "Payload data" is text data encoded as UTF-8.  Note that a
      particular text frame might include a partial UTF-8 sequence;
      however, the whole message MUST contain valid UTF-8.  Invalid
      UTF-8 in reassembled messages is handled as described in
      Section 8.1.
```

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-8.1 - Handling Errors in UTF-8-Encoded Data
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-10.7 - Handling of Invalid Data
Updated. The utf-8 validation has been completed and now 100% of the autobahn tests pass.
Now passing with 100%.
@victorhurdugaci @muratg
Assuming the tests work now on Win7, :shipit:
:shipit:
CLA approved. @Tratcher to merge.
@muratg can you find someone to work on this?
ZeroMask is a debug setting so that you can read the data in Netmon. It just makes the masking step a no-op so it should work with any server.
@Tratcher I moved the ZeroMask discussion to https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/issues/27 so we could treat it separately.

ZeroMask is a debug setting so that you can read your data in Netmon. 0 is a legal mask per spec, just not recommended (see http://xkcd.com/221/). It makes the masking step a no-op, but servers shouldn't even notice.
I think once you invoke an XKCD comic it becomes truth.

commit_comments.body: This generates "Offset" instead of "buffer.Offset", since `nameof()` uses the name of the last component in a qualified name. There's no parameter named "Offset". (And I think the idea with `Argument...Exception`s is that they should just refer to the parameter and not to a property path.)

Ah, good point. The invalid argument is really `buffer`, which happens to have a sub-property with a bad value.

Logged https://github.com/aspnet/WebSockets/issues/44

Nice catch!
It's useful to uncomment in some cases, but it was causing warnings in the current setup so I commented it out.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
-﻿<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
+<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
 <configuration>
     <startup> 
-        <supportedRuntime version="v4.0" sku=".NETFramework,Version=v4.5" />
+        <supportedRuntime version="v4.0" sku=".NETFramework,Version=v4.5.1"/>
review_comments.body: Our project generation requires 4.5.1 now but everything is still built against .net 45
Recommend parens around (b & 0x3F) for clarity.
missing access modifier
nit: use the null propagating operator instead?
nit: var

@davidfowl Should we move the configure/configureServices to the context directly?  I don't think we gain much putting them together inside StartupMethods on the context at least.  We can still keep the class around for the Startup helpers
The result of `nameof(buffer.Count)` is just "Count", correct?
@Tratcher you are right
Just realized that PlatformHelper is useless here because CoreCLR... I'll see what I can figure out.

The problem here is not merely the parameter name - it's that the message to the developer won't make much sense. The message will now say something like "The 'buffer' parameter is out of range. Current value: -123". However, that is clearly not true. It's the `Offset` _property_ of the `buffer` parameter that is out of range.

This exception should probably not be an `ArgumentOutOfRangeException` at all. It should just be an `ArgumentException` saying that `The`Offset`property cannot be negative and cannot be greater than the size of the`Array`property's length.` and pass in `buffer` as the name of the argument.
Shall we use this message **$"The {buffer.Offset} property cannot be negative and cannot be greater than the size of theArrayproperty's length."** instead
That looks the same as what I said, no? BTW don't use string interpolation here because once these go into RESX files you can't use string interpolation - so stick to `string.Format`.
it's just called `application` elsewhere.
Remove webroot.
you can move this in the top level deps node
